title.narrative: Plan International Sweden, Skydd av barn i väpnad konflikt, 2017-2022
Plan International Sweden, Support to children in armed conflict, 2017-2022

description.narrative:
In situations of conflict children are particularly vulnerable. Existing threats such as violence or trafficking are exacerbated and new ones appear, including the risk of recruitment into armed groups. At the same time, the protective environment, both in the community and the official child protection services, is weakened by a lack of safety, security and a dependence on humanitarian assistance. In situations of protracted conflicts, it is necessary to find solutions that bridge the common humanitarian-development dichotomy.
Plan International's programming is guided by a child-centred community development approach, working with children, their families, communities, organizations and local governments to bring about positive change regardless of the context in which they live. The project will focus on three areas: the Central African Republic, Myanmar and Tanzania. Thematic focus will include strengthened community resilience against (re-)recruitment of child soldiers among internally displaced children in the CAR and Myanmar (Rakhine) and Burundian refugees in Tanzania. Activities include psychosocial support, life skills training, vocational training, parenting programmes and economic empowerment, as a vital prerequisite for attaining stable, peaceful and cohesive societies. The main target group for this intervention are young boys and girls aged 12 – 29.

Insatsen bidrar till att stärka resiliens hos unga flickor och pojkar som befinner sig i utdragna konflikter för att åstadkomma en mer stabil miljö där risken för rekrytering av barn till väpnade grupper minskar och barn och ungas säkerhet istället ökar. Barn och unga blir i konfliktsituationer särskilt utsatta då redan existerande hot om våld och trafficking eskaleras och nya dyker upp, så som risken för rekrytering av barn till väpnade grupper. Samtidigt försvagas den skyddande miljön, både inom samhället och av myndigheter, i och med bristen på säkerhet och det nya beroendet av humanitärt stöd. Vid mer utdragna konflikter är det även nödvändigt att finna lösningar som länkar humanitär hjälp och utvecklingsbistånd. Insatsen fokuserar på tre områden: Central Afrikanska Republiken, Myanmar och Tanzania. Tematiskt fokus inkluderar stärkande av samhällens resiliens mot (åter-)rekrytering av barnsoldater bland flyktingbarn i CAR, Myanmar (Rakhine) och Tanzania. Planerade aktiviteter inkluderar psykosocialt stöd, tillgång till skolor, stärkande av livskunskaper, föräldraansvar, yrkesutbildning och ekonomisk egenmakt av unga människor som en vital förutsättning för att uppnå samhällen som är mer stabila och fredliga med stark social sammanhållning. Målgrupp för insatsen är pojkar och flickor i åldrarna 12 till 29.
Krisen i Centralafrikanska Republiken har lett till nästan en miljon interna flyktingar. Bland dessa är pojkar och flickor bland de värst drabbade och närmare 13 000 barn har enligt FN rekryterats till väpnade grupper. Olika ansatser har gjorts med hjälp av internationella aktörer för att släppa dessa barn fria, men risken är fortfarande stor att rekrytering fortsätter. När barnen släpps får de stöd bland annat från Plan med att återförenas med sina familjer och återintegreras i samhället. Plan arbetar med bland andra Unicef för att stärka samhällets resiliens genom att belysa de faktorer som kan bidra till att driva barn och unga att gå med i väpnade grupper.
I en fortsatt instabil kontext med underliggande spänningar som karakteriserar den utdragna krisen i centrala Rakhine i Myanmar påverkas barn bland annat genom bristande tillgång till säker skolgång. Samtidigt nås inte alltid ungdomar av stöd som oftast riktar sig antingen till barn eller kvinnor och män mer generellt. Detta trots att unga pojkar och flickor är väldigt sårbara och utsätts för psykosocial stress, tidiga äktenskap, barnarbete, trafficking och annat utnyttjande. Utöver utökad tillgång till skolgång erbjuder insatsen 16 byar i Minbya aktiviteter som riktar sig specifikt åt ungdomar. För att öka resiliens och stärka skyddet av barn erbjuds bland annat psykosocialt stöd och mentorskap, vägledning till familjer och värdfamiljer om ansvarsfullt föräldraskap och påverkansarbete gentemot lokala myndigheter och ledare. Samtidigt kommer fredsbyggande aktiviteter erbjudas genom allaktivitetshus för att stärka den sociala sammanhållningen, resiliens och egenmakt hos unga pojkar och flickor. Bland dessa ingår bland annat konflikthantering och yrkesutbildning och ett höjt medvetande kring ungdomars mervärde som positiva aktörer i samhället.
Liknande aktiviteter planeras i Tanzania där över 253 000 burundiska flyktingar befinner sig sedan säkerhetsläget försämrades 2015. Internationellt stöd till skydd av barn i flyktinglägren är för närvarande bristfällig med socialarbetare som ansvarar för ungefär 200 barn var då stöd behöver prioriteras för andra mer akuta humanitära behov. Plans insats i flyktinglägren i västra Tanzania (Kibondo) kommer utöka antalet socialarbetare och bygga vidare på andra redan existerande mekanismer till stöd framför allt för ensamkommande flyktingbarn. Liknande stöd saknas inom regionens utvecklings strategi och humanitära insatser har inte resurser för att ta sig an detta i en situation som blivit mer utdragen. Samtidigt ökar riskerna för utnyttjande och rekrytering av barn.

title.narrative: Amendment to the Agreement on Strengthening resilience of at risk children and youth in situations of protracted conflict
Grant agreement Sida - Plan International Sverige, Strengthening resilience of at risk children and youth in situations of protracted conflict
Beslut om insats, Plan Sverige - Stöd till barn i väpnad konflikt

description.narrative: The narrative report, submitted on 6 March 2020, covers the period 1 November 2018 to 31 October 2019 and provides detailed descriptions of progress made towards outcomes in each of the three countries CAR, Tanzania and Myanmar along with a situation analysis. The narrative report also describes how the conflict and gender perspectives have been reflected, how work has aimed to strengthen the humanitarian development nexus, a brief on lessons learned, financial monitoring and an updated analysis of risks. Along with the narrative report, Plan also shared its mid-term formative assessment report. Progress was further discussed during the annual review meeting on 21 April 2020 and is summarized below. Outcome 1: Children and youth are protected from risk of recruitment into armed groups. All 3 country interventions have contributed to strengthening the protective environment in which adolescent and young people evolve. In the case of CAR, activities directly aimed at preventing recruitment (and encouraging release), target on the one hand parents/caregiver and the wider community as well as armed groups members, with awareness raising and skills. At the end of year 2: 68% of the targeted parents and caregivers declared not supporting their children joining armed groups. 84% of the awareness-raising target groups stated that their level of knowledge of the consequences of the association between children with armed groups / forces had increased. Outcome 2: Adolescents and youth are empowered to contribute actively to building a more inclusive, equitable, cohesive and peaceful society All 3 countries have continued to build young people’s knowledge, capacities and skills on peace-related topics and methodologies although not without challenges, as further explained below. In Myanmar, the project team developed a peace education curriculum and trained some of the youth facilitators as well as members of local civil society organizations as trainers. Outcome 3: Conflict affected adolescents, youth and families have increased resilience and protective capacities Plan International has continued to strengthen the resilience of targeted adolescents and young people against child protection risks, including on violent mobilization. In Tanzania, the project has focused on vulnerable adolescents and young people and provided them with life skills and vocational training while targeting caregivers with parenting skills programmes. Country-specific progress and challenges CAR In CAR, the peace and reconciliation agreement signed in February 2019 had a positive impact on the situation with less violence noted in the Kaga-Bandoro area. There was also a reported release of 1253 children associated with armed groups. Community-based efforts for child protection were held through Child Protection Committees (RECOPE) and youth clubs. Activities range from awareness raising on child protection and informative campaigns for the prevention of recruitment and use of children in armed groups; referral of child protection cases to appropriate services; working with the national child protection cluster to ensure a legal framework; training/capacity building, including of armed groups’ leaders on child rights. Guidelines have been developed through the Ministry for Women, Family and Child Protection Promotion on the temporary placement of unaccompanied and separated children who have been released from armed groups into foster families as it was noted that many of the children needed care prior to being able to trace and reunite them with their families. A second outcome focused on empowering adolescents and youth to contribute actively to building a more inclusive, equitable, cohesive and peaceful society. This included life skills sessions, psychosocial support and reintegration of former CAAFAG into the formal school system through Child/Youth friendly spaces. Positive impact was recorded, such as: increased child protection, including against sexual violence and abuse and recruitment by armed groups; decreased emotional distress; decreased behavioural problems evidenced by less fighting; increased interactions with peers and less solitary behaviour; and learning of important life skills such as hygiene management, literacy and numeracy. Joint socio-cultural activities and sports also promoted mutual understanding, respect and peaceful cohabitation between members of Muslim and Christian communities. Over the two years, 350 children (46% girl) have been reintegrated to formal schooling with 77% completing to the next grade. Overall, with improvements to the security situation, activities have advanced more during Y2, particularly in the area of Kaga-Bandoro. Myanmar The project in Myanmar focuses on the educational and economic empowerment of 800 vulnerable adolescents (12-24 years) and 1,150 community members as a vehicle for long-term peace and prosperity and prevention of violent conflict in Rakhine State. The intensifying conflicts in 2018 and 2019 delayed certain parts of the project. In 2019, half of the 25 activities were delayed because of the lack of access to the field, difficulties in testing the peacebuilding/conflict sensitive curriculum, challenges in conducting livelihood skills trainings and bridging activities across ethnic communities. The conflict has also restricted Plan from going to villages with a need to instead conduct remote monitoring. Nonetheless, around 50 youth facilitators in 22 community-based Youth Centres in 16 villages were trained on peace education and life skills training leading to improved capacities in centre management, data collection, teaching techniques and communication. Non-Formal Education opportunities were also provided with access to teachers’ and student kits and materials. Through the various activities and community-mobilization events, youth facilitators have also gained more trust among their communities. Due to restrictions in travel, dialogue opportunities and cooperation across traditional divides were not possible. As the MTR noted, rather than strengthening social cohesion through ‘bridging’ between different groups, the project was instead able to focus on ‘bonding’ activities to strengthen cohesion within groups. Tanzania While Tanzanian and Burundians authorities made visits to refugees camps to reassure them of a safe return to Burundi, the presidential elections in Burundi in May 2020 increased concerns among refugees. Added to this, the humanitarian needs in the camps increased while there was an overall decrease in funding towards these needs. The implementation of the project faced additional challenges due to bans and restrictions imposed by the Tanzanian authorities. Awareness raising on risks of recruitment into armed groups including for caregivers/foster parents were conducted and no case of recruitment was reported. However, gathering data continues to be a challenge as community members do not feel comfortable talking about recruitment. 814 (518 female, 296 male) conflict affected adolescents were given life skills and vocational training. Challenges due to closures of markets had a negative impact on youth being able to conduct business upon finalizing the training sessions. Positive parenting training was provided to 900 (576 female and 324 male) parents, foster parents and caregivers, resulting in more warmth and empathy between caregivers and children. MTR Through internal lessons learned workshops in the three country-office, a mid-term formative assessment was conducted in the later half of 2019. The assessment showed that a majority of outputs had been met, although commonly with delays due to external challenges in the three different contexts. Among the highlighted lessons learned were the importance of clarifying concepts such as social cohesion, peacebuilding and nexus before the start of the project and translating them into tangible results and actions for the project teams. Another recommendation was to ensure more tailored sensitization activities to different groups to achieve greater impact. This for instance applies to information regarding child recruitment where messaging for parents of abducted children would need to be different compared to messaging for parents who themselves force their children to join armed groups. Added to this is an identified need for a deeper understanding of the underlying causes behind voluntary and forced recruitment. The MTR is a valuable read and could assist both Plan and Sida on future programming on Children and Armed Conflict, Children Associated with Armed Forces and Armed Groups as well as on Youth, Peace and Security and social cohesion. For year three, Plan has incorporated recommendations from the findings, including promoting youth engagement in peacebuilding and reconciliation processes in CAR by capitalizing on Plan’s access and collaboration with various youth groups and networks; emphasizing on peace education in Myanmar; and increasing social cohesion and preparing children, youth and caretakers in camps in Tanzania on risks they may face upon return to Burundi. Yearly Assessment meeting with Sida On 21 April, Plan and Sida met for the annual review meeting. Plan presented progress, challenges and opportunities where also triple nexus and linkages to the YPS agenda were made. A positive side-effect to the project has been that Plan has been able to apply a nexus approach to other areas of its programming, such as through the new Sida-CIVSAM framework (2019-2024), and through internal restructuring along geographical lines instead of the former, more siloed, humanitarian-development divide. Plan International is furthermore developing a position paper on triple nexus that will provide conceptual guidance to country programming.
